oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucilia coeruleiviridis (Diptera: Calliphoridae) larval growth rates at three constant temperatures
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Evan Lampert
Hutton, Deven
Mondor, Edward
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: blow fly
development
ectotherm
forensic entomology
postmortem interval
blow fly
entomology
postmortem interval
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lucilia coeruleiviridis is one of the most common calliphorids in the Eastern US. Despite its ubiquity, almost nothing is known about its larval development, rendering it unusable for minimum postmortem interval (mPMI) estimates. Here, we report the results of rearing L. coeruleiviridis at 22°C, 29°C, and 36°C to determine egg mass survivorship and development time in hours to (and length of) first instar, second instar, third instar, and wandering stages. Larvae were more likely to die and grew more slowly when reared at 22°C compared to those reared at warmer temperatures. The mean development times until larvae began to wander were 89.95h at 22°C, 69.24h at 29°C, and 51.02h at 36°C. Regression analyses revealed a mean minimum developmental temperature of 9.8°C. Future studies using more temperatures, particularly warmer temperatures, are recommended, however, this study shows that L. coeruleiviridis growth is temperature dependent and this species develops best at warm temperatures, corresponding with its geographic distribution. Development times and minimum developmental temperatures presented here can be used for generating mPMI estimates using L. coeruleiviridis in the Southeastern US.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Journal of Forensic Entomology; Vol. 1 (2023): The Journal of Forensic Entomology
